trial_identification.studytitle: High Flow support versus Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) support in non-acute respiratory support for preterm infants from 30 weeks corrected gestation
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In preterm infants from 30 weeks corrected gestation, how does High Flow respiratory Support compared with Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) respiratory Support affect the infant's short term respiratory outcomes?

conditions.healthcondition: respiratory failure in preterm infants from 30 weeks corrected gestation

interventions.interventions:
high flow gas support (minimum 4 litres/min - maximum 6 litres/min in 25% oxygen)
Dose size determined by level of support needed (ie. all will start on 6 litres/min, then be reduced as needed)
It will be administered continuously via nasal cannula for a maximum of 4 weeks (can be weaned off earlier if no support is necessary).
interventions.comparator:
CPAP (no minimum - maximum 5 cm H20 pressure in <= 25% oxygen)
Dose size determined by level of support needed (ie. all will start on 5 cm H20 pressure, then be reduced as needed).
It will be administered continuously via nasal cannula for a maximum of 4 weeks (can be weaned off earlier if no support is necessary).

primaryOutcome.outcome: Failure of High Flow - will be determined if the baby was placed on CPAP or higher level of respiratory support.

Stability on treatment- number of bradycardia/apnoea episodes per day
Determined by the need for tactile stimulation by staff in order to revert the bradycardic episode back to normal.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: daily collection during 4 week study period

primaryOutcome.outcome: Chronic lung disease (CLD) at 36 weeks will be determined as the need for oxygen or respiratory support at the corrected gestation of 36 weeks.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: at 2 weeks after intervention cessation; at 36 weeks corrected gestational age of enrolled infant

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Nasal damage assessed by clinical observation
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: daily collection during 4 week study period

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Time to full feeds- reached when the infant is receiving 120 ml/kg/day of milk.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: during the infant's stay in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Growth- weight, head circumference, length. Assessed using PEAPOD.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: twice weekly during infant's stay in NICU

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Clinical abdominal distension assessed by clinical observation
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: daily collection during 4 week study period

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Number of kangaroo holds during treatment assessed from patient bedside notes
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: daily collection during 4 week study period

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Infants are eligible to enrol if- 1. They are at least 5 days old 2. They are at least 30 weeks corrected gestation 3. They are less than 32 weeks corrected gestation 4. They are CPAP dependent but not requiring greater than 5cm H2O preessure or greater than 25% oxygen 5. Parental consent is obtained
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Infants are ineligible to enroll if- 1. There is a major congenital malformation present 2. They are suffering severe asphyxia 3. Clinical airway obstruction is present 4. Parental consent is not obtained 5. Receiving more than CPAP/5 in 25% inclusion

trial_design.concealment:
Prior to randomisation, researchers will ensure infants are eligible by making sure they are a minimum of 30 weeks corrected gestation, a minimum of 5 days old and obtain parental consent.
After that, dependence to CPAP needs to be determined. If an eligible infant fails the trial-off CPAP, they need to be immediately randomised via the computer system by either a study researcher or attending staff member:
trial_design.sequence: Stratified allocation by gestational age and gender. Then randomisation by using a randomisation table created by a computer software.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Liverpool Health Service Locked Mailbag 7103 Liverpool NSW 1871

ethicsAndSummary.summary: A pilot study to investigate the short term outcomes of infants undergoing CPAP or High Flow treatment from 30 weeks corrected gestation.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Human Research and Ethics Commitee (South West Sydney)
